, it's shopping mall and some nicer garden restaurants.

Neu-Isenburg has almost 36,400 inhabitants and was a sleeping town until the industy took advantage of the good location and the proximity to the airport. Nowadays it's a very multicultural city with many people that live only temporary in town. It still has a nice old town center but the city is spread out and after the business hours it's calm.

Neu-Isenburg is very well connected and has entries/exits to the Autobahns A3, A5 and A661 plus the federal street B43 (shortcut to the airport). In the morning and evening rush hour most Autobahns are congested so plan additional time if you travel to Frankfurt or to the trade fair. There is a direct bus to/from the airport (Bus 651 from Airport Terminal 1) that leaves twice per hour and the railway is well connected to Frankfurt main station.
Neu-Isenburg is part of the RMV

and therefore connected to the public transport system of the greater Frankfurt area. Within the center you can easily walk or taxis are available in front of the Hugenottenhalle. Keep in mind that the public transport stops early in the evening, so if you intend to go around after 8PM check the schedules or have a bike.

value: content=Huge shopping mall that has only recently been partly under renovation for a new brighter impression.

Neu-Isenburg has a huge varity of restaurants due to the large numbers of business travellers and non-German population.
There are dozens of food stalls in the Neu-Isenburg Zentrum Mall that offer cheap food over lunch time.

There are many phone/call shops along Frankfurter Str. for long-distance calls that partialy also have some internet terminals. Ownership often changes, so look for clean shops.
